title: Liouville's Theorem on Transcendentals
content:
**Wiedijk #18**: First Explicit Transcendental Number (1844)

Liouville proved: **Numbers that can be approximated "too well" by rationals must be transcendental.**

This was the **first constructive proof** that transcendental numbers exist — before Cantor's diagonal argument (1874), before e (1873), before π (1882)!

title: Liouville's Approximation Theorem
content:
**Key Result**: If α is algebraic of degree n ≥ 2, then:

$$\left|\alpha - \frac{p}{q}\right| > \frac{c}{q^n}$$

for some constant c > 0 and all rationals p/q.

**Proof idea**:
1. Let P(x) be α's minimal polynomial (degree n)
2. For p/q ≠ α: q^n · P(p/q) is a nonzero integer, so ≥ 1
3. Mean Value Theorem bounds the difference
4. This gives the 1/q^n lower bound

title: Liouville Numbers
content:
**Definition**: ξ is a **Liouville number** if for every n ≥ 1, there exist p, q with q > 1 such that:

$$0 < \left|\xi - \frac{p}{q}\right| < \frac{1}{q^n}$$

These numbers can be approximated **better than any polynomial bound allows**.

By the approximation theorem, such numbers cannot be algebraic!

title: Main Theorem
content:
**Theorem**: All Liouville numbers are transcendental.

**Proof by contradiction**:
1. Suppose ξ is Liouville and algebraic of degree n
2. Approximation theorem: $|\xi - p/q| > c/q^n$
3. Liouville property: $|\xi - p/q| < 1/q^{n+1}$
4. For large q: $1/q^{n+1} < c/q^n$ — contradiction!

title: Liouville's Constant
content:
**The first explicit transcendental** (1844):

$$L = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} 10^{-n!} = 0.110001000000000000000001...$$

The 1's appear at positions 1!, 2!, 3!, 4!, ... = 1, 2, 6, 24, 120, ...

**Why L is Liouville**: Partial sums give approximations p/q where:
$$|L - p/q| < 2 \cdot 10^{-(m+1)!} < 1/q^m$$

This beats any polynomial bound!

title: Properties of Liouville Numbers
content:
**Surprising facts**:

1. **Uncountable**: Despite being "rare", there are as many Liouville numbers as real numbers!
2. **Measure zero**: Almost all reals are NOT Liouville (probability 0)
3. **Closed under operations**: If L is Liouville, so is L + r and r·L for rational r ≠ 0

So: Liouville numbers are simultaneously "everywhere" (uncountable) and "nowhere" (measure zero).

title: Roth's Improvement
content:
**Roth's Theorem (1955, Fields Medal)**:

$$\left|\alpha - \frac{p}{q}\right| > \frac{c}{q^{2+\varepsilon}}$$

for ANY algebraic irrational α and ANY ε > 0!

**History of the exponent**:
- Liouville (1844): n (degree)
- Thue (1909): n/2 + 1 + ε
- Siegel (1921): 2√n + ε
- Roth (1955): **2 + ε** (optimal!)

The exponent 2 cannot be improved (Hurwitz's theorem).
